stem: An 82-year-old client with a history of CAD presents to a crowded ED with 'nausea and epigastric discomfort.' Based on the documentation in the ED Triage & Surveillance Log, which factor represents the root cause of the resulting Sentinel Event (Cardiac Arrest in the waiting room)?

options.text: Failure to perform a screening 12-lead EKG within 10 minutes of arrival.
The 180-minute wait time in the lobby.
The patient's age and history of CAD.
The overcrowding of the Emergency Department.

rationale.correct: The **root cause** of this sentinel event is the **failure to perform a screening EKG (a1)**. According to national standards (AHA/ACC), any patient over 50 (especially with cardiac history) presenting with 'atypical' symptoms (nausea, epigastric pain, indigestion) must receive a **12-lead EKG within 10 minutes** of arrival to rule out a STEMI. While the wait time (a2) and overcrowding (a4) are contributing factors, the clinical failure to recognize an 'MI mask' led directly to the unmonitored cardiac arrest.
clinicalPearls: Myocardial infarction in the elderly, women, and diabetics often presents as 'Indigestion' or 'Silent' (no chest pain).
Goal for EKG: < 10 minutes for ANY suspected cardiac symptom.
A Sentinel Event is an unexpected occurrence involving death or serious physical/psychological injury.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing 'Wait time' (a2) because it was 3 hours.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Wait times are unfortunate but common; the **clinical error** (missing the EKG) is what makes it a preventable sentinel event. In Root Cause Analysis (RCA), look for the 'Standard of Care' that was violated.

mnemonic.title: 10-Min Rule
mnemonic.expansion: Gut pain + Old? EKG in 10. Don't let them wait, check their heart again.
